s.text: Could this possibly be the same Jessica Mathews who had debated me on Charlie Rose last year, scowling as she told viewers environmental optimism was an appalling notion?
Her repeated use of that word--"success"--was especially galling.
Her repeated use of that word--"success"--was especially galling.

She rejected my contention that ecological initiatives represent "the leading postwar triumph for American government," and slammed me for using the word "success" to describe environmental regulation.
Her repeated use of that word--"success"--was especially galling.

She rejected my contention that ecological initiatives represent "the leading postwar triumph for American government," and slammed me for using the word "success" to describe environmental regulation.
I had hit the Al Gore glass ceiling.

But the book appeared just as Newt Gingrich seemed poised to repeal the 20th century and public opinion was retreating to the view that nature is doomed.
Several Democratic senators seemed taken but--or so I was told--were asked to steer clear by the vice president's office.
